action_content: One of the key promises of the UDC during the 2024 election campaign was the creation of 450,000 to 500,000 jobs, addressing high unemployment rates <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241122/281608130987055</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) pledged to focus on creating jobs, strengthening financial systems, and upholding democracy in its 2024 election manifesto <citation>https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/africa/2024-09-02-botswanas-president-masisi-launches-bdp-manifesto-ahead-of-2024-elections</citation>.

A proposed minimum wage increase to P4,000 represents a 203% jump from the current rate of P1,321 for general workers <citation>https://www.regalcapital.org/p/should-botswana-increase-minimum-wage-to-p4000</citation>.

The UDC's manifesto for the 2024 Botswana elections emphasizes "inclusive growth and quality lives," with promises including the creation of 500,000 jobs in five years <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>.

The UDC manifesto focuses on education, housing (building 100,000 affordable homes in five years), and healthcare reforms, including comprehensive health insurance for all citizens <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-manifesto-highlights/</citation>.

South African President Cyril Ramaphosa and other political parties have congratulated Botswana on its peaceful elections and the end of the BDP's 58-year rule <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/politics/ramaphosa-political-parties-congratulate-botswana-on-elections-which-ended-bdps-58-year-rule-20241102</citation>.

Masisi's concession occurred before the final results were officially announced, with the BDP trailing in fourth place in parliamentary elections <citation>https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2024/11/02/2003826272</citation><citation>https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/nov/1/botswana-president-mokgweetsi-masisi-conceded-part/</citation>.

The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) launched its 2024 manifesto, focusing on improving lives through a high-wage economy and democratic governance <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82075</citation>.
Duma Boko was sworn in as the new President of Botswana on November 8, 2024 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/8/botswana-swears-in-duma-boko-as-new-president</citation>.

The UDC government affirms its commitment to fulfilling its manifesto promises from the 2024 general elections <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/govt-to-fulfil-promises</citation>.

Duma Boko addressed the press following his victory in the 2024 Botswana elections, expressing gratitude and outlining his vision for the country <citation>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S1Fh0mZ0Lw8</citation>.

The UDC manifesto includes commitments to increase the average salary to P10,000 or more, achieve an annual economic growth rate of at least 10%, and launch a National Community Service program with a monthly allowance of P2,500 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>.

The UDC pledged to more than double the minimum wage to 4,000 pula ($300) per month <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-elections-ruling-party-seeks-to-extend-58-years-in-power</citation>.
Concerns existed around the minimum wage during the election period <citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation>.

A petition called on the Botswana government to fulfill its election promise to increase the student living allowance to P2,500.00 per month <citation>https://www.change.org/p/p-2-500-allowance-petition-for-botswana-government-to-increase-living-allowance</citation>.

Businesses have warned that sectors like manufacturing and agriculture, which rely heavily on low-wage labor, would face severe challenges with the proposed minimum wage increase <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/business-botswana-not-ready-for-p4k-minimum-wage/</citation>, suggesting a phased implementation <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/business-botswana-not-ready-for-p4k-minimum-wage/</citation>.

The UDC will transform Botswana into a regional hub in Tourism and Hospitality, Transportation and Infrastructure, Banking and Finance, Innovation and ICT, Education and Health <citation>https://thepanafrikanist.com/speech-delivered-at-the-launch-of-the-2024-manifesto-of-the-umbrella-for-democratic-change/</citation>.

President Boko had pledged to raise the minimum wage to P4000, increase student allowances to P2500, and enhance the old age pension fund to P1800 by the end of November 2024 <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/president-boko-expresses-uncertainty-on-when-government-will-pay-p4000-minimum-wage/</citation>.

President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat after preliminary results indicated that the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) had lost its parliamentary majority in the recent election <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/africa/news/botswanas-president-masisi-concedes-defeat-in-election-20241101</citation>, ending the party's 58-year rule <citation>https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/world/archives/2024/11/02/2003826272</citation>, despite the countryâ€™s reputation for stable governance <citation>https://bulawayo24.com/index-id-news-sc-national-byo-247401.html</citation> and electoral integrity <citation>https://bulawayo24.com/index-id-news-sc-national-byo-247401.html</citation>.

In his inauguration speech, President Boko emphasized the need for unity and collaboration among Batswana <citation>https://1stafrika.com/2024/11/04/botswanas-new-president-duma-boko-i-dare-not-fail-in-commitment-to-progress/</citation>, calling it "a new political dawn" and expressing gratitude for Botswana's enduring commitment to democracy <citation>https://myafrikamag.com/president-duma-bokos-inauguration-a-vision-of-unity-progress-and-renewal-for-botswana/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a significant victory, marking the end of the BDP's nearly six-decade reign <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-president-concedes-defeat-in-election-ruling-party-s-58-years-in-power-end-/7847324.html</citation>, with Duma Boko declared the election winner <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>.

President Duma Boko's inauguration speech called for unity and marked a "new political dawn" for Botswana <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/politics/together-we-usher-a-new-political-dawn-says-botswana-president-duma-boko-in-inauguration-speech-20241108</citation><citation>https://myafrikamag.com/president-duma-bokos-inauguration-a-vision-of-unity-progress-and-renewal-for-botswana/</citation>.

Duma Boko's inauguration speech is a resonant appeal for unity, hope, and transformation in Botswana, marking the beginning of his leadership <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/20-biggest-takeaways-from-president-duma-bokos-inauguration-speech/</citation>.

action_content: Four candidates were confirmed for Botswana's 2024 presidential election, including the incumbent President Mokgweetsi Masisi <citation>https://iafrica.com/high-court-confirms-four-candidates-for-botswanas-upcoming-presidential-election/</citation>.

In the 2024 elections, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) won a majority with 59.0% of the vote, securing 36 out of 61 National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>.

The voter registration exercise for the October 2024 General Elections concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) had ruled the country for 58 years since independence but was ousted in the 2024 elections <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>.

Botswana faces economic and political struggles, including rising unemployment and economic uncertainty <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

In the 2024 parliamentary elections, 10.6% of the candidates were women (28 out of 264), compared to 5.7% in 2019 (12 out of 210) <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The IEC commenced recruitment and training of poll staff in preparation for the 2024 elections <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/iec-botswana-provides-comprehensive-update-on-2024-general-elections-preparations/</citation>.
Leaders from the BDP, BCP, UDC, and BPF were declared as presidential candidates for the 2024 general elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.
The 2024 general elections in Botswana were the 13th post-independence elections <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>.
The BDP's share of seats decreased from 38 (out of 57) in 2019 to 4 in 2024 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The voter registration tally for the 2024 general elections represented a 7 percent increase compared to the 2019 figures <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-exceeds-historic-1-million-mark-in-voter-registration/</citation>.

In Botswana's electoral system, 57 of the 65 members of the National Assembly are directly elected by plurality vote in single-seat constituencies, while 6 are nominated by the President and approved by the National Assembly <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>.
The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) coalition won 36 seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation>.

Botswana uses a first-past-the-post (FPTP) electoral system where 61 constituencies elect members of parliament <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/understanding-botswanas-electoral-system-challenges-and-opportunities/</citation>.
Presidential nominees for the 2024 General Elections had to be validated by the High Court <citation>https://www.africauptodate.com/botswana-general-elections-2024-begin</citation>.
The Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won five seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

To form a government in Botswana, a party needs to secure at least 31 seats in the National Assembly <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/understanding-botswanas-electoral-system-challenges-and-opportunities/</citation>.

President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat on Nov 1, 2024, after the BDP lost to the UDC <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>, ending the ruling party's 58 years in power <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>.

The BDP lost its 58-year majority in the National Assembly elections on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation>.

Voters in Botswana rejected the country's long-serving governing party, marking a political earthquake in the diamond-rich nation <citation>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) missed its voter registration target of 1.3 million for the 2024 elections, registering only 736,424 voters <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/iec-misses-voter-registration-target/news</citation>.

The 2024 Botswana general election is considered a historic moment and a triumph of democracy in Southern Africa, with Botswana maintaining regular democratic elections since its independence in 1966 <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.
Over 190 independent candidates registered for the 2024 general elections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-registers-over-190-independent-candidates/</citation>.
The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats (24.6%) in the 2024 election <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>.

The UDC emerged as the leading party with 36.9% of the total votes in the 2024 election results, while the BDP secured 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) registered a total of 1,038,275 voters for the 2024 general elections, with 1,036,243 registering in Botswana and 2,032 registering abroad <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/over-one-million-voters-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

## Campaign

The lead-up to the 2024 Botswana general election was marked by energetic public discourse and diverse party platforms <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/botswana-2024-general-elections/</citation>. Key issues reflected the evolving priorities of Batswana, including concerns about the minimum wage <citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation>, rising unemployment, and economic uncertainty <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

The ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), which had been in power for 58 years since independence <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>, launched its manifesto with a pledge to focus on creating jobs, strengthening financial systems, and upholding democracy <citation>https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/africa/2024-09-02-botswanas-president-masisi-launches-bdp-manifesto-ahead-of-2024-elections</citation>. President Masisi described the manifesto as a realistic program grounded in the realities faced by Batswana <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81509</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), which ultimately won the election, centered its campaign on "inclusive growth and quality lives" <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. A key promise was the creation of 450,000 to 500,000 jobs in five years to combat the staggering unemployment rate <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241122/281608130987055</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. The UDC also pledged to increase the average salary to P10,000 or more, achieve an annual economic growth rate of at least 10%, and launch a National Community Service program with a monthly allowance of P2,500 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. A significant proposal was to more than double the minimum wage to 4,000 pula ($300) per month <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-elections-ruling-party-seeks-to-extend-58-years-in-power</citation>, although concerns were raised about the feasibility and potential impact on businesses <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/business-botswana-not-ready-for-p4k-minimum-wage/</citation>. Businesses, particularly those in manufacturing and agriculture, warned of severe challenges and suggested a phased implementation of the minimum wage increase <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/business-botswana-not-ready-for-p4k-minimum-wage/</citation>.

Other parties, such as the Botswana Congress Party (BCP), also presented their manifestos, with the BCP focusing on improving lives through a high-wage economy and democratic governance <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82075</citation>.

action_content: President Mokgweetsi Masisi was seeking a second term in the 2024 election <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation><citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation>.

General elections in Botswana are held every five years after the expiry of one life of Parliament <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>.

Botswana's elections are governed by the 1966 Constitution, the 1969 Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act, the 1968 Electoral Act and the 2012 Local Government Act <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>.

The 2024 Botswana general election was held on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation><citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation><citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation><citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation><citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240904/botswanas-general-election-set-for-october-30-1068142775.html</citation>.

The President is mandated by the Constitution to call for general elections within 60 days of Parliament's dissolution <citation>https://www.facebook.com/BotswanaGovernment/posts/sequence-of-events-towards-the-12th-parliament-dissolution-of-parliamentin-terms/2450889864993657/</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) provided a detailed briefing on the preparations for the 2024 General Elections <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/iec-botswana-provides-comprehensive-update-on-2024-general-elections-preparations/</citation>.

The 12th Parliament of Botswana was dissolved on September 5th, 2024 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>, in accordance with Section 90, Sub-Section 3 of the Constitution <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>.

Parliament is expected to be dissolved in the months leading up to the election, following constitutional guidelines <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/iec-botswana-provides-comprehensive-update-on-2024-general-elections-preparations/</citation>.
General elections were held in Botswana on October 16, 2009, alongside local elections <citation>https://everything.explained.today/2009_Botswana_general_election/</citation>.

Botswana's electoral system is based on the first-past-the-post (FPTP) or simple majority system <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation><citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections-2.html</citation>.

## Election date and timeline

The Botswana general election was held on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation><citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation><citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation><citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation><citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240904/botswanas-general-election-set-for-october-30-1068142775.html</citation>. This marked the 13th post-independence general election in the country <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>.

The lead-up to the election involved several key events. Voter registration concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>. action_content: General elections in Botswana are held every five years after the expiry of one life of Parliament <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured 36.9% of the total votes in the 2024 election, surpassing the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) which received 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The 12th Parliament of Botswana was dissolved on September 5th, 2024, following Section 90, Sub-Section 3 of the Constitution <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>.

Botswana has maintained regular democratic elections since gaining independence in 1966, with the 2024 election being a triumph of democracy in Southern Africa <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

Botswana's elections are governed by the 1966 Constitution, the 1969 Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act, the 1968 Electoral Act and the 2012 Local Government Act <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>.
The 2024 election saw over 190 independent candidates register <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-registers-over-190-independent-candidates/</citation>.

President Boko pledged to raise the minimum wage to P4000, increase student allowances to P2500, and enhance the old age pension fund to P1800 by the end of November 2024 <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/president-boko-expresses-uncertainty-on-when-government-will-pay-p4000-minimum-wage/</citation>.

Duma Boko's inauguration speech emphasized unity and marked a new political era, expressing gratitude for Botswana's commitment to democracy <citation>https://myafrikamag.com/president-duma-bokos-inauguration-a-vision-of-unity-progress-and-renewal-for-botswana/</citation><citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/politics/together-we-usher-a-new-political-dawn-says-botswana-president-duma-boko-in-inauguration-speech-20241108</citation>.

In addition to Duma Boko and Mokgweetsi Masisi, leaders from the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) and Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) were also presidential candidates in 2024 <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) actually registered 1,038,275 voters for the 2024 general elections, including 1,036,243 within Botswana and 2,032 abroad <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/over-one-million-voters-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

## Preface

The 2024 Botswana general election, held on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation><citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation><citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation><citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation><citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240904/botswanas-general-election-set-for-october-30-1068142775.html</citation>, marked a watershed moment in the nation's political landscape. For the first time in 58 years since independence, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) was ousted from power <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>, as the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a majority with 59.0% of the vote, securing 36 out of 61 National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>. This election saw Duma Boko of the UDC emerge victorious, while the incumbent President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>.

Several critical issues dominated the electoral discourse, including rising unemployment <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation> and a proposed minimum wage increase to P4,000 <citation>https://www.regalcapital.org/p/should-botswana-increase-minimum-wage-to-p4000</citation>, a significant jump from the existing P1,321 <citation>https://www.regalcapital.org/p/should-botswana-increase-minimum-wage-to-p4000</citation>. The UDC campaigned on a platform of "inclusive growth and quality lives," promising the creation of 450,000 to 500,000 jobs <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241122/281608130987055</citation> and reforms in education, housing, and healthcare <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-manifesto-highlights/</citation>.

The peaceful transfer of power following the election has been hailed as a triumph of democracy in Southern Africa <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, underscoring Botswana's commitment to regular democratic elections since gaining independence in 1966 <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. Duma Boko's inauguration marked a new political era <citation>https://myafrikamag.com/president-duma-bokos-inauguration-a-vision-of-unity-progress-and-renewal-for-botswana/</citation>, with a strong emphasis on unity and progress <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/politics/together-we-usher-a-new-political-dawn-says-botswana-president-duma-boko-in-inauguration-speech-20241108</citation>.

action_content: The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) won a majority of the vote (59.0%) and secured 36 of the 61 elected National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation> and this was followed by the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) with 15 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) victory in the 2024 election is considered the biggest upset in the country's election history <citation>https://www.africanews.com/2024/11/01/botswana-udc-supporters-celebrate-election-win/</citation>.

Only 28 women stood for parliament out of 258 contestants in 2024, representing 10.85%. Only three women won their seats, representing 4.92% of the 61 seats <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/women-in-botswana-make-up-54-of-voters-but-less-than-10-of-parliament-political-parties-can-change-that</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party's (BDP) share of support dropped to 31% in the October 2024 elections, resulting in only four out of 61 constituencies <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>.

Key electoral issues in 2024 included the economy, unemployment, the minimum wage, and social services <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The new legislature will have 69 members, increased from 65, due to an increase in directly elected members from 57 to 61 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured 36.9% of the total votes, while the BDP secured 30.2%, and the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 20.7% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

In the 2024 elections, the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) won 15 seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82945</citation>.

The voter turnout in the 2024 parliamentary elections was significant, with 81% of registered voters participating <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured victory, marking the end of the BDP's uninterrupted rule since independence <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The 13th parliament was sworn in on November 7, 2024, and President Duma Gideon Boko delivered the first State of the Nation Address (SONA) on November 19, 2024 <citation>https://connect.sivioinstitute.org/2025/02/17/the-umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-100-days-in-office-tracking-government-actions-inactions-against-electoral-promises-in-botswana/</citation>.

The 2024 elections saw a significant shift in Botswana's political landscape as the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) lost power after 58 years, marking a historic change <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation><citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation><citation>https://www.cnn.com/2024/11/01/africa/botswana-party-loses-election-masisi-boko-intl/index.html</citation><citation>https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20241101-botswana-governing-party-losing-six-decade-rule-early-tallies-show</citation><citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/breaking-masisis-bdp-ousted-after-58-years-in-historic-2024-election/</citation><citation>https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/opinionista/2024-11-05-electoral-revolution-by-centre-left-coalition-wipes-out-58-year-rule-of-botswana-democratic-party/</citation><citation>https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-11-01/botswana-election-ends-ruling-party-58-years-in-power/104551974</citation><citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation> .

action_content: The 2024 Botswana general election has opened up discussions about electoral reform, particularly regarding proportional representation (PR) <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>., which could lead to a fairer reflection of voter support in the National Assembly <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/botswana-elections-2024-just-but-unfair/</citation>.

Economic growth in Botswana is projected to slow to 1% in 2024, a decline from 2.3% in the previous year and 5.5% in 2022 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>.

Inequality, climate change, and a political feud were driving factors in the 2024 election <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

Former President Ian Khama formed the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) just before the 2019 election <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>.

Botswanaâ€™s peaceful transition of power after the 2024 elections could offer a blueprint for change in neighboring nations struggling with authoritarianism <citation>https://www.princetonpoliticalreview.org/international-news/botswanas-political-shake-up-what-the-ruling-partys-historic-loss-means-for-democracy-in-sadc</citation>.

Sales of rough diamonds at Debswana, a critical source of state revenue, decreased by nearly 50% in the first half of 2024 <citation>https://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/botswana-holds-an-election-with-new-economic-challenges-for-long-ruling-party/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) claimed 36 seats in the October 2024 elections while the Botswana Democratic Party's support dropped to 31%, resulting in only four constituencies <citation>https://theconversation.com/botswanas-election-shock-analyst-reflects-on-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-242811</citation>.

Under the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system, the BDP received 31% of the popular vote but secured only 4 seats, revealing an imbalance between votes received and representation <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/botswana-elections-2024-just-but-unfair/</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party's (BDP) popularity had been declining, falling below 50% for the first time in the 2014 elections <citation>https://www.jacarandafm.com/news/news/results-botswana-governing-party-losing-six-decaderule/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) has unveiled its manifesto for the 2024 Botswana elections, emphasing on \"inclusive growth and quality lives\" <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>.

action_content: Botswana held its 13th post-independence general election in 2024 <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) has set up approximately 2,880 polling stations across Botswana and 48 in foreign territories to accommodate Batswana citizens living abroad for voter registration <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>.

The voter registration process for the 2024 general elections started on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://africanyouthnews.com/botswana-begins-voter-registration-for-upcoming-election-despite-challenges/</citation><citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/voter-registration-for-next-years-general-elections-in-botswana-to-start-friday</citation>.

Botswana uses the First Past The Post (FPTP) electoral system for National Assembly and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.
The Botswana National Assembly indirectly elects the President for a 5-year term, which can be renewed once <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/4357/</citation>.
The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) commenced voter registration for the 2024 general elections <citation>https://allafrica.com/stories/202311010072.html</citation>.

In the 2019 election, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) secured a majority, winning 38 out of the 57 contested seats, with a voter turnout of 84% <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/4357/</citation>.
The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) of Botswana provides updates and ensures free and fair elections <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/</citation>.
On October 30, Botswana held general elections for the unicameral National Assembly and local councils <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>.

Mokgweetsi Masisi (BDP), Duma Boko (UDC), Mephato Reatile (BPF), and Dumelang Saleshando (BCP) took part in the Presidential debate in Gaborone on October 24, 2024 <citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation>.
Only 7 out of the BDP's 62 parliamentary candidates for the 2024 elections were women <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/only-7-women-make-bdps-62-parliamentary-candidates-for-2024/</citation>.

## Results

The 2024 Botswana general election marked a historic shift in the nation's political landscape, ending the Botswana Democratic Party's (BDP) nearly six-decade rule since gaining independence in 1966 <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>. Voters rejected the long-serving governing party in what has been described as a political earthquake <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.

In terms of seat distribution, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a majority of the vote with 59.0%, gaining 36 out of the 61 elected National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) won 15 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) secured five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The BDP's share of seats drastically declined from 38 in 2019 (out of 57) to a mere 4 (out of 61 directly elected seats) in the 69-member Parliament <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

Concerning the vote share, the UDC secured 36.9% of the total votes, surpassing the BDP, which received 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) maintained a substantial presence with 20.7% of the votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP)'s share of support dropped to 31% in the October 2024 elections, resulting in only four out of 61 constituencies <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) victory in the 2024 election is considered the biggest upset in the country's election history <citation>https://www.africanews.com/2024/11/01/botswana-udc-supporters-celebrate-election-win/</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

action_content: The 2024 election result is a seismic moment of change that ended the ruling party's 58 years in power since independence from Britain in the 1960s <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>.

The 2024 voter registration saw a 7% increase compared to 2019 figures. Women accounted for 54% of registered voters, men 46%, and youth 32% <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-exceeds-historic-1-million-mark-in-voter-registration/</citation>.

In 2019, 925,478 people registered to vote and the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) received 406,561 votes <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/over-one-million-voters-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) concluded the General Voters Registration Exercise for the October 2024 General Elections on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

The voters' registration for the 2024 General Election started on January 5, and ended on February 3, 2023, during which the IEC registered only 736,424 prospective voters <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>.
The 2019 elections saw around 900,000 voters <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) aimed for a voter registration target of 80%, projecting a voting population of 1.7 million for the 2024 general election, aiming for approximately 1.3 million registered voters, which would represent the highest turnout in Botswana's history <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

A total of 319,632 eligible voters were registered since the beginning of the national voter registration exercise on January 5, 2024, with 130,541 people registered in week two <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-numbers-decline-maroba-expresses-no-worry/news</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) emerged as the leading party with 36.9% of the total votes in the 2024 Botswana election, while the long-ruling BDP secured 30.2% of the votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) came into power following their October 30, 2024, General Elections win <citation>https://connect.sivioinstitute.org/2025/02/17/the-umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-100-days-in-office-tracking-government-actions-inactions-against-electoral-promises-in-botswana/</citation>.

action_content: The voter registration for the 2024 general election started on January 5 and ended on February 3, 2023 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>.

The IEC dispelled fears of electoral fraud related to recent ID issues, stating that multiple registrations and underage registrants are common mistakes that will be addressed through voter roll inspections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-dispels-electoral-fraud-in-recent-id-issues/</citation>.

Voter registration challenges, including late or absent registration clerks, potentially undermined the integrity of the registration process for the 2024 general election <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

The UDC filed an urgent application seeking an interdiction and a declaratory order against the IEC a day before the voter election registration exercise was to commence nationwide (31-Oct-23) <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/iec-postpones-voter-registration-process</citation>.
The IEC postponed voter registration in preparation for the registration exercise and educating the voters about elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/74700</citation>.

Early voting in Botswana was affected by irregularities, including a shortage of ballot papers, leading the electoral body to order a re-run in some areas <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-advance-voting-marred-by-ballot-paper-shortages/7830447.html</citation>.

Some stakeholders attributed challenges in voter registration to the IEC's failure to adequately educate eligible voters <citation>https://www.up.ac.za/news/post_3252222-up-expert-opinion-up-expert-assesses-botswanas-state-of-readiness-for-2024-elections</citation>.

The IEC warned opposition parties against making what it called \"reckless\" claims of poll rigging before the October 30 general election <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-electoral-body-warns-opposition-about-rigging-claims/7826626.html</citation>.

The IEC postponed the registration for the 2024 general election to put in place measures that would help deliver quality registration <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/iec-postpones-voter-registration</citation>.

The indefinite suspension of voter registration was a blow to election preparations and heightened tensions between the ruling party and the opposition leading up to the 2024 vote <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/botswana-electoral-turmoil-deepens</citation>.

Botswana's 13th parliamentary elections presented the most formidable challenge the ruling BDP has faced since coming to power, due to economic discontent, the return of former president Khama, and internal divisions within the BDP <citation>https://africaelects.com/2024/10/28/botswana-inside-the-countrys-most-competitive-election-to-date/</citation>.

The UDC filed an urgent application seeking an interdiction and a declaratory order against the IEC a day before the voter election registration exercise was to commence nationwide (31-Oct-23) <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/iec-postpones-voter-registration-process</citation>.

The government of Botswana should take steps to address gaps in the legal framework such as fixing of the election date, finalisation of the constitution review process and state funding of political parties which may cause political instability in the future if not resolved <citation>https://www.chr.up.ac.za/latest-news/3836-what-you-need-to-know-about-botswana-s-elections-expected-to-take-place-in-october-this-year</citation>.

The judge stated in his ruling that the IEC should show cause why an order cannot be issued to allow UDC to observe and monitor the national elections registration exercise, including having the UDCâ€™s agents recording the names and national identity card numbers of the people registering to vote and recording the serial numbers of the registration booklets for each and every registration day at the opening and closing <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/iec-postpones-voter-registration-process</citation>.

Compared to the past elections where the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) registered 747 601 eligible voters in the first phase of votersâ€™ registration, this time around there is a decline of 11, 177 voters, only registering 736,424 prospective voters during the first phase which started on January 5, and ended on February 3, 2023 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>.

There was an increase in female candidates in the 2024 polls compared to the previous election. In 2024, 10.6% (28 out of 264) candidates were women, as opposed to 5.7% (12 out of 210) in 2019 <citation>https://www.mewc.org/index.php/tools/political-participation-a-election-monitroing/2024-elections-monitoring/12395-botswana-parliamentary-elections-2024</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) postponed the voter registration process to implement measures aimed at ensuring a high-quality registration process <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/74700</citation> and to reassess their readiness for the 'sensitive' national exercise <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/74700</citation>.

The IEC has set a historic record by registering over 80% of Batswana who are eligible to vote for the upcoming General Election <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/mmegi/20240705/281539411163089</citation>.

The IEC encountered challenges such as registration clerks arriving late or not showing up, leaving only one clerk to manage the station, which prompted the IEC to engage reserve clerks <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

The anticipated voting population for the 2024 general election, as projected by the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC), is 1.7 million, with the Commission setting a target of 80 percent, approximately 1.3 million <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

The IEC achieved 69% of their targeted 1.7 million voters registered in the first phase of voter registration which started on January 5, and ended on February 3, 2023 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>.

The IEC declared yet another supplementary voter registration period due to a failure to attract the desired number of registered voters during the initial supplementary registration phase, which was held exclusively at IEC offices <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-declares-yet-another-supplementary-voter-registration/news</citation>.

Botswana's national elections attracted a huge turnout of citizens, with notable queues forming as early as dawn <citation>https://eng.fatshimetrie.org/2024/10/30/strong-voter-turnout-in-botswana-national-elections/</citation>.

action_content:
## Voter registration

In Botswana, every citizen aged 18 years and above is eligible to register to vote in National and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php?title=Botswana_-_Obtain_a_Voters_card</citation>, <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>. The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) conducts voter registration, a process which involves eligible citizens verifying their inclusion on the voter's roll or registering to be added <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

The voter registration for the 2024 general elections began on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://africanyouthnews.com/botswana-begins-voter-registration-for-upcoming-election-despite-challenges/</citation>, <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/voter-registration-for-next-years-general-elections-in-botswana-to-start-friday</citation>. Supplementary voter registration periods were also announced, with one running from February 26 to March 15, 2024 <citation>https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/supplementary-voting-registration-2024-elections-easylaw-botswana-9hdgf</citation>. To register, citizens are required to present themselves to a Registration Officer with a valid National Identity Card (Omang) <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>, <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>. The IEC also set up approximately 2,880 polling stations across Botswana and 48 in foreign territories to accommodate Batswana citizens living abroad <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>.

The IEC, however, faced several challenges during the registration process, including some registration clerks arriving late or not showing up <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>. There was also a surge in illegal voter registrations <citation>https://apadiaspora.net/botswana-poll-body-warns-of-surge-in-voter-registration-irregularities/</citation>. To combat this, the IEC dispelled fears of electoral fraud related to recent ID issues, stating that multiple registrations and underage registrants are common mistakes that will be addressed through voter roll inspections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-dispels-electoral-fraud-in-recent-id-issues/</citation>. The IEC also postponed the voter registration process to ensure quality registration <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/74700</citation>.

### Background of opposition parties before the election

The 2024 Botswana general election saw a number of opposition parties vying for power, most notably the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), the Botswana Congress Party (BCP), the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF), and the Alliance for Progressives (AP) <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/botswanas-political-landscape-gearing-up-for-the-2024-general-election</citation>. The UDC is a coalition of left-leaning parties aiming to unseat the BDP <citation>https://www.theafricareport.com/366164/botswanas-presidential-election-meet-the-candidates/</citation>. Led by Duma Boko, the UDC was formed in 2012 by three political parties: the Botswana National Front, the Botswana Movement for Democracy, and the Botswana People's Party <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2024/11/12/botswanas-new-president-who-is-duma-boko-and-what-does-he-stand-for/</citation>. Boko served as the Leader of the Opposition in the National Assembly from 2014 to 2019 <citation>https://kids.kiddle.co/Duma_Boko</citation>. In the 2024 election, the UDC secured 36.9% of the total votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) has promised to "save Botswana" and committed to offering an average monthly living wage of 4,000 pula <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. Dumelang Saleshando is the leader of the BCP <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. The BCP secured 15 seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) was formed by ex-President Ian Khama's followers <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation> just before the 2019 election <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>. Mephato Reatile leads the BPF <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. The BPF won five seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The Alliance for Progressives (AP) is a dynamic and forward-thinking political movement dedicated to transforming Botswana into a nation of equal opportunities, inclusive growth, and sustainable prosperity <citation>https://www.ap.org.bw/about/</citation>.

Former President Ian Khama split from the BDP and supported the BPF <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.

Yandani Boko resigned from his position as MP for Mahalapye East <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/youngest-botswana-mp-resigns-rumors</citation> and active politics <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/78284</citation> citing emotional strain <citation>https://pressug.com/mp-resigns-from-parliament-citing-emotional-strain/</citation>.

Section 71 of the Constitution of Botswana requires Members of the National Assembly to take an Oath of Allegiance, which is administered by the Clerk of the National Assembly. <citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>.

Dumelang Saleshando replaced Duma Boko as Leader of the Opposition in the National Assembly after the 2019 general election because of Boko's defeat <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Botswana_general_election</citation>.

Prior to the ban on floor crossings in 2023, the National Assembly experienced defections, with two BDP MPs and two UDC MPs switching to the UDC and BDP, respectively <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Botswana_general_election</citation>.

Bill No.14 2020 for MPs and Bill No. 15 of 2020 (Local Government (Amendment) for Councillors seeks to put an end to floor crossing <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/politicians-shameful-hypocrisy-over-floor-crossing/</citation>.

Since 2019, the opposition won about 80% of local government by-elections <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>.

The Botswana Parliament first debated the proposal to amend the constitution to outlaw floor crossing in 1998 and again in 2011 <citation>https://constitutionnet.org/news/botswanas-piecemeal-constitutional-reform-initiative-banning-floor-crossing</citation>.

The constitutional amendment mandating that MPs resign if they switch parties mid-term is aimed at stabilizing governance and respecting voter mandates <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>.

The story of floor crossing in Botswana political history is almost as old as the country's parliamentary democracy is <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/politicians-shameful-hypocrisy-over-floor-crossing/</citation>.

President Masisi stated that the review of floor-crossing laws was a priority if his government was given a fresh mandate in the 2019 general elections <citation>https://net.zimeye.org/2019/08/27/tired-of-losing-mps-botswana-president-wants-floor-crossing-laws-reviewed/</citation>.

action_content:
### Composition of parliament

The Botswana National Assembly is a unicameral legislature. The most recent 2024 election and preceding years have seen some shifts in its composition. The new legislature consists of 69 members <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, an increase from the previous 65. This number includes 61 directly elected members <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation> who are chosen through a First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, six specially elected members who are indirectly elected by the National Assembly <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, and two *ex officio* members: the President and the Speaker <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The Speaker may be appointed from outside the National Assembly <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The 2019 election saw the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) win a majority with 38 of the 57 seats being voted on <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/4357/</citation>. Voter turnout was 84% <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/4357/</citation>. However, the 2024 election resulted in a significant shift in power, ending the BDP's 58-year rule <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured 36 seats <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation>, while the BDP's representation plummeted to just 4 seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats and the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. Overall voter turnout was 79% in the 2024 elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82973</citation>.

Prior to 2023, the National Assembly saw instances of floor crossing. For example, two BDP MPs and two UDC MPs defected to the UDC and BDP, respectively <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Botswana_general_election</citation>. To address this, a ban on floor crossing was implemented in 2023, mandating that MPs resign if they switch parties mid-term <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>. This amendment aims to stabilize governance and respect voter mandates <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>.

Notably, Yandani Boko resigned from his position as MP for Mahalapye East during this period <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/youngest-botswana-mp-resigns-rumors</citation>.

In the 2024 parliamentary elections, only 28 women stood for parliament out of 258 contestants, representing 10.85% of the total candidates. Only three women won their seats, representing 4.92% of the 61 seats <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/women-in-botswana-make-up-54-of-voters-but-less-than-10-of-parliament-political-parties-can-change-that</citation>.

The UDC challenged the results of the 2019 Botswana elections in court, focusing on 16 parliamentary constituencies won by the BDP <citation>https://www.reuters.com/article/world/botswana-opposition-challenges-election-result-in-court-idUSKBN1Y00QO/</citation>.\n

In 2019 the SADC Electoral Observation Mission (SEOM) was present in Botswana <citation>https://www.sadc.int/sites/default/files/2021-06/Botswana_SEOM_Preliminary_Statement.pdf</citation> with 925, 478 registered voters <citation>https://www.sadc.int/sites/default/files/2021-06/Botswana_SEOM_Preliminary_Statement.pdf</citation>.\n

In the 2019 election, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) won 29 national assembly seats, which constituted 51% of the vote <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2019/10/25/botswanas-ruling-party-bdp-wins-general-election-chief-justice/</citation>.\n

In the 2019 Botswana election, there were three parties contesting the election, comprising two parties and one coalition (UDC), with 192 candidates (175 men, 17 women) vying for 57 seats <citation>http://archive.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2041_E.htm</citation>.\n

The fairness of Botswana's elections has been a point of contention, with the opposition claiming that the electoral system, the electoral body, and the political environment favor the ruling party <citation>https://www.academia.edu/40308652/The_2019_Elections_in_Botswana_Context_History_and_Future_Chris_Brown</citation>.\n

In 2019, Botswana's Electoral Amendment Act of 2016, which introduced electronic voting, was a source of controversy, with the opposition Botswana Congress Party (BCP) claiming the system was susceptible to manipulation in favor of the ruling BDP <citation>https://freedomhouse.org/country/botswana/freedom-world/2019</citation>.\n

Ian Khama's strained relationship with his successor, Mokgweetsi Masisi, significantly impacted the 2019 elections, with Khama supporting the opposition in an attempt to unseat Masisi and the BDP <citation>https://converis.ub.bw/converis/portal/detail/Publication/9692048?lang=en_GB</citation>.\n

In 2019, 925,478 people registered to vote in Botswana <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>, with a turnout of 84.1% <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>.\n
The 2019 Botswana general election had a voter turnout of 84%, with 777,943 votes cast <citation>https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Fluctuating+voting+trends+in+Botswana.-a0779611920</citation>.\n

In the 2019 Botswana General Election, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) secured a resounding victory, marking their 12th consecutive win since the country's independence in 1966 <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2019/10/27/he-mokgweetsi-masisi-bdp-wins-botswana-2019-general-election/</citation> giving President Mokgweetsi Masisi a mandate to fulfill the party's promises <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2019/10/27/he-mokgweetsi-masisi-bdp-wins-botswana-2019-general-election/</citation>.\n

Masisi's recall of a party candidate over dubious charges provoked popular anger <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>.

Over 190 independent candidates were registered for the 2024 general elections, with the number likely to increase before the nomination deadline <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-registers-over-190-independent-candidates/</citation>.

Claims of poll rigging were made by opposition parties ahead of the election <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-electoral-body-warns-opposition-about-rigging-claims/7826626.html</citation>.

Aspiring presidential nominees must be validated by the High Court before the election <citation>https://www.africauptodate.com/botswana-general-elections-2024-begin</citation>. There were 4 validated presidential nominees for the 2024 General Elections <citation>https://www.africauptodate.com/botswana-general-elections-2024-begin</citation>.
The International Monetary Fund forecasts 1% growth for 2024 <citation>https://africaelects.com/2024/10/28/botswana-inside-the-countrys-most-competitive-election-to-date/</citation>.

The 12th Parliament of Botswana was dissolved on September 5th, 2024, with a writ of election issued on the same day <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>.

Masisi was nominated as the presidential candidate for the ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) at its national congress <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>.

A man was registered as a voter in Mogoditshane town, Kweneng district, Botswana, on Jan. 5, 2024 <citation>https://africanyouthnews.com/botswana-begins-voter-registration-for-upcoming-election-despite-challenges/</citation>.
The UDC won the elections on 30 October 2024 and its first 100 days in power will conclude on 7 February 2025 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/2024-what-a-year-it-was/</citation>.
The IEC is projecting a voting population of 1.7 million <citation>https://allafrica.com/stories/202311010072.html</citation>.

Voters in Botswana cast votes for local councilors, members of parliament, and the president on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://www.princetonpoliticalreview.org/international-news/botswanas-political-shake-up-what-the-ruling-partys-historic-loss-means-for-democracy-in-sadc</citation>.

The 2024 Botswana general election was held on October 30th, with President Mokgweetsi Masisi seeking a second term <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation>, <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation>, <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>, <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation>, <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>, <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation>, <citation>https://www.africauptodate.com/botswana-general-elections-2024-begin</citation>.

The party of Botswana's opposition candidate Duma Boko has been declared the election winner over incumbent President Mokgweetsi Masisi <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>.
The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) is actively preparing to ensure a smooth election process <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/botswana-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

Masisi indicated that the bill about floor crossing might return after the October 2024 elections if his party wins <citation>https://www.southernafricalitigationcentre.org/elections-a-critical-juncture-in-botswanas-democratic-evolution/</citation>.
Voter registration started from October 4-31 <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/index.php/news-detail/74192</citation>.

The primary elections for parliamentary and council seats in the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) were held late and were marred by irregularities <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>. There was popular anger over Masisi's recall of a party candidate <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>.

Observers from the UDC were expected to record names, identity card numbers, and serial numbers of registration books of voters during the voter registration period <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>.

### Previous election

The 2019 Botswana General Election, held on October 23, 2019, marked the 12th consecutive win for the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) since the country's independence in 1966 <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2019/10/27/he-mokgweetsi-masisi-bdp-wins-botswana-2019-general-election/</citation>. This victory secured President Mokgweetsi Masisi's mandate to implement the BDP's promises <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2019/10/27/he-mokgweetsi-masisi-bdp-wins-botswana-2019-general-election/</citation>.

Key political parties in the 2019 election included the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), and the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) <citation>http://archive.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2041_E.htm</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) secured a majority, winning 38 out of the 57 contested seats <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/52572</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) won 15 seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20191023/</citation>, the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won 3, and the Alliance for Progressives (AP) won 1 <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/52572</citation>.

Voter turnout was significant, with 84% of registered voters participating <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>, representing 777,943 votes cast <citation>https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Fluctuating+voting+trends+in+Botswana.-a0779611920</citation>. 925,478 people registered to vote in 2019 <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>.

The election saw some controversies, including concerns about the fairness of the electoral system <citation>https://www.academia.edu/40308652/The_2019_Elections_in_Botswana_Context_History_and_Future_Chris_Brown</citation> and allegations of double voting <citation>https://www.biznews.com/global-citizen/2019/12/05/botswana-election-rigged-forensics-justice</citation>. The Electoral Amendment Act of 2016, introducing electronic voting, also caused controversy <citation>https://freedomhouse.org/country/botswana/freedom-world/2019</citation>.

Former President Ian Khama's strained relationship with his successor, Mokgweetsi Masisi, significantly impacted the 2019 elections, with Khama supporting the opposition in an attempt to unseat Masisi and the BDP <citation>https://converis.ub.bw/converis/portal/detail/Publication/9692048?lang=en_GB</citation>.

International observer missions, such as the ECF-SADC, were present to observe the election <citation>https://www.eisa.org/pdf/bot2019ecf.pdf</citation> and hailed the polls as credible and a fair reflection of the will of the people <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/52573</citation>.

Following the election, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) challenged the results in court, focusing on 16 parliamentary constituencies won by the BDP <citation>https://www.reuters.com/article/world/botswana-opposition-challenges-election-result-in-court-idUSKBN1Y00QO/</citation>.

The party that secures at least 31 seats in the National Assembly has the ability to form a government under Botswana's electoral system <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/understanding-botswanas-electoral-system-challenges-and-opportunities/</citation>.

In his inauguration speech, President Duma Boko emphasized unity and collaboration among Batswana <citation>https://1stafrika.com/2024/11/04/botswanas-new-president-duma-boko-i-dare-not-fail-in-commitment-to-progress/</citation>.

Early voting in Botswana was marred by irregularities such as a shortage of ballot papers <citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-s-advance-voting-marred-by-ballot-paper-shortages/7830447.html</citation>.
The voter turnout for the 2024 Botswana election was 79%, with 824,014 votes cast out of 1,038,275 registered voters <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82973</citation>.

The IEC set a target of registering 80% of the anticipated voting population of 1.7 million for the 2024 election <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

President Duma Boko's inauguration is viewed as a symbol of hope and transformation for Botswana <citation>https://myafrikamag.com/president-duma-bokos-inauguration-a-vision-of-unity-progress-and-renewal-for-botswana/</citation> and it is a beginning of his leadership <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/20-biggest-takeaways-from-president-duma-bokos-inauguration-speech/</citation>.

The new legislature will comprise 69 members (an increase from 65), and there are also six 'specially elected members' and two ex officio members <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The dissolution of the 12th Parliament occurred on September 5, 2024, and the Constitution mandates that general elections be called within 60 days of Parliament's dissolution <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>.
The UDC's 100 days in office concludes on February 7, 2025 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/2024-what-a-year-it-was/</citation>.
Women made up 54% of registered voters for the 2024 election <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-exceeds-historic-1-million-mark-in-voter-registration/</citation>.

Prior to the 2024 election, Dumelang Saleshando replaced Duma Boko as the Leader of the Opposition in the National Assembly after Boko's defeat in the 2019 election <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Botswana_general_election</citation>.

The BDP has dominated Botswana's polls since 1969, securing 38 of 57 seats in the 2019 general election <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>.
Botswana's president is indirectly elected by the National Assembly for up to two 5-year terms <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>.

Supplementary voter registration was open to every citizen of Botswana who has attained the age of 18 years and in possession of a valid national identity card <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/index.php/news-detail/77952</citation>.

The leaders of Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), Botswana Congress Party (BCP), Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) and Botswana Patriot Front (BPF) have been declared as the presidential candidates for the 2024 general elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.

The First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) majority system is used for both National Assembly and Local Government elections in Botswana <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The High Court has confirmed four candidates for Botswana's upcoming presidential election on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://iafrica.com/high-court-confirms-four-candidates-for-botswanas-upcoming-presidential-election/</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) started voter registration for the 2024 general elections <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>.
Voters in Botswana rejected the country's long-serving governing party in a result that marks a political earthquake <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.

Early results from Botswana's election on October 31, 2024, pointed to a loss of power for the party that has ruled for 58 years <citation>https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2024-10-31/botswana-election-early-tallies-point-to-shock-loss-for-ruling-party</citation>.
For the 2024 General Elections, there were 4 validated presidential nominees <citation>https://www.africauptodate.com/botswana-general-elections-2024-begin</citation>.
The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) has dominated the polls since 1969 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) has governed Botswana since its independence from Britain in 1966 <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-bdp-masisi-7ae583e904f30e4fe3df3e6de2ecefb6</citation>.

The UDC won the national contest securing a majority of the vote (59.0 per cent) and 36 of the 61 elected National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>.

The President of Botswana introduced the 62 parliamentary candidates representing the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) for the upcoming 2024 elections <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/only-7-women-make-bdps-62-parliamentary-candidates-for-2024/</citation>.

President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat in the 2024 Botswana general election during a press conference in Gaborone on November 1, 2024, ending the ruling party's 58 years in power <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>.
