action_content: The 2024 Botswana election saw the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secure a victory with 36.9% of the votes, while the BDP received 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation> and the Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 20.7% of the votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) government faces the challenge of restoring sound governance after nearly six decades of BDP rule <citation>https://www.polity.org.za/article/great-expectations-as-democracy-wins-in-botswana-2024-11-18</citation>.

President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat on November 1, 2024, after the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) lost to the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) in the general elections <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>.

Botswana Democratic Party's loss in the 2024 elections can be attributed to factors such as deteriorating living conditions and high unemployment rates (27% overall and 32% for youth) <citation>https://mo.ibrahim.foundation/news/2024/guest-blog-ngn-expert-perspectives-africas-2024-election-year</citation>.

The UDC won 35 seats, securing an outright majority in parliament, and pledged a new economic strategy focused on well-paying jobs <citation>https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.

The opposition Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) now has the majority in parliament and can form the next government, marking a historic defeat for the previous ruling party <citation>https://www.france24.com/en/africa/20241101-botswana-governing-party-losing-six-decade-rule-early-tallies-show</citation>.

Duma Boko, leader of the UDC, attributed the party's victory to its message of economic and democratic restoration <citation>https://www.voaafrica.com/a/botswana-s-opposition-udc-attributes-victory-to-economic-messages/7850249.html</citation>.

The victory of the Duma Boko-led Umbrella for Democratic Change in the 2024 Botswana general election signifies a unique transition for Botswana's democratic legacy and its international standing <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/udc-victory-in-botswana-what-is-happening-here-is-unique-transition-in-every-way</citation>.
The UDC proposed a National Health Insurance Scheme to prioritize access to quality healthcare <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) won 36 out of 61 directly elected seats in Parliament, while voter turnout exceeded 80% <citation>https://issafrica.org/iss-today/great-expectations-as-democracy-wins-in-botswana</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) lost its 58-year majority in the National Assembly elections on October 30, 2024, securing only 4 of the 61 directly elected seats <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation>.

The UDC's victory with 36.9% of the vote illustrates the impact of the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system, where a party can form a government without securing over 50% of the votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

Following the UDC's election victory in Botswana, there's been a shift in governance, responding to calls for social change after decades of BDP rule <citation>https://informationstreamer.com/2024/12/24/botswanas-udc-victory-a-shift-in-governance-amid-economic-challenges/</citation>.

The triumphant UDC government faces the task of restoring sound governance after nearly six decades of BDP rule <citation>https://www.polity.org.za/article/great-expectations-as-democracy-wins-in-botswana-2024-11-18</citation>.

The new legislature comprises 69 members, including 61 directly elected, six "specially elected members", and two ex officio members <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The 13th parliament was sworn in on November 7, 2024, with President Duma Gideon Boko delivering the first State of the Nation Address (SONA) on November 19, 2024 <citation>https://connect.sivioinstitute.org/2025/02/17/the-umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-100-days-in-office-tracking-government-actions-inactions-against-electoral-promises-in-botswana/</citation>.

Botswana's president, Mokgweetsi Masisi, conceded defeat on Friday, November 1, 2024, after preliminary results indicated his party's loss of parliamentary majority <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>.

President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded electoral defeat to Advocate Duma Boko shortly after the 2024 general elections <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/change-of-government-highlights-historic-2024</citation>.

### Seat redistribution

Botswana employs a First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) majority system for both National Assembly and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. This system dictates that the candidate with the most votes in a constituency wins the seat <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. Following the October 30, 2024, general election <citation>https://www.princetonpoliticalreview.org/international-news/botswanas-political-shake-up-what-the-ruling-partys-historic-loss-means-for-democracy-in-sadc</citation>, the seat distribution in the National Assembly saw a dramatic shift. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) emerged as the leading party, securing 36 of the 61 directly elected seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>, marking a significant increase from the 15 seats they held after the 2019 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20191023/</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) won 15 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) secured 5 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>. The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), which had dominated Botswana's politics since 1969 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>, experienced a historic defeat, plummeting to just 4 seats <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation> from 38 in 2019 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

This outcome highlights the potential disparities that can arise under the FPTP electoral system, where a party can win the majority of seats without necessarily securing the majority of total votes cast <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. For example, in the 2024 election, the UDC won with 36.9% of the total votes, while the BDP secured 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. As an alternative, a Proportional Representation (PR) system would allocate seats more closely mirroring the actual voter preferences <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, potentially leading to a more representative legislature.

### MPs not standing for re-election

The 2024 Botswana general election saw a number of Members of Parliament not standing for re-election for various reasons. Some MPs' political careers came to an end due to losses in primary elections, while others opted for retirement <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. For instance, in the Gaborone North constituency, the incumbent MP, Mpho Balopi, had announced that he would not seek re-election in the 2024 general elections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/animosity-rises-as-bdp-primaries-near/</citation>. action_content: Botswana uses the First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) majority system for National Assembly and Local Government elections, but there is no direct presidential election <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>.
The date of presidential nominations was set for Saturday, September 28th, 2024, at the Gaborone High Court <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>.

The Presidential Election (Supplementary Provisions) Act Cap 02:01 supplements the constitutional provisions regarding presidential elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>.

The Returning Officer examines nomination papers to ensure compliance with section 5 of the Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/Presidential+Elections+Supplementary+Provisions+ch02-01.pdf</citation>.

The High Court in Gaborone is located in the CBD (Central Business District) <citation>https://www.africabizinfo.com/BW/high-court</citation> and operates from Monday to Friday, 7:30 AM to 4:30 PM <citation>https://www.africabizinfo.com/BW/botswana-high-court-371-8000</citation>.

The date for submitting the names of presidential candidates was September 28, and for parliamentary and local council candidates, it was October 4 <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation>.

Nomination day for presidential candidates is the first Saturday following the expiry of 20 days after each dissolution of the National Assembly <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/StatutesActpdf/1969Actpdf/PRESIDENTIAL+ELECTIONS+(SUPPLEMENTARY+PROVISIONS)+ACT,+41+OF+1969.pdf</citation>.

Botswana's electoral legal framework includes the 1966 Constitution, the 1969 Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act, the 1968 Electoral Act, and the 2012 Local Government Act <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) is responsible for conducting and supervising elections, referenda, and ensuring elections are conducted efficiently, properly, freely and fairly <citation>https://www.gov.bw/ministries/independent-electoral-commission</citation>.

Chief Justice Terrence Rannowane confirmed the four presidential candidates for the 2024 election after they submitted their applications <citation>https://sundiatapost.com/4-nominees-submit-application-for-botswana-presidency-election-body/</citation>, <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.

Contact information for the Gaborone High Court includes phone number (+267) 371 8000 and fax number (+267) 391 5119 <citation>https://cms2.gov.bw/ministries/ministry-justice-and-correctional-services</citation>.

To be nominated, candidates must produce an official receipt of P500.00 for National Assembly elections or P100.00 for Council elections, or deposit the said amounts in cash with the Returning Officer <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/parties-and-candidates.html</citation>.
Nomination of presidential candidates followed the expiry of 20 days after the dissolution of the National Assembly on September 5 <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.
The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) was established in 1997 to improve transparency and fairness in the electoral process <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/about.html</citation>.

President Masisi urged the Botswana Police Service (BPS) to train officers on election duties and law enforcement expectations <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/mmegi/20240223/281625310236019</citation>.

The Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act makes provision ancillary to the Constitution of Botswana for the election of a President <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/consolidated-statutes/principle-legislation/presidential-elections-supplementary-provisions</citation>.

The Botswana Constitution of 1966 outlines the nomination process for presidential elections in Sections 30-35 <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation>.

Biggie Butale of the Botswana Republican Party (BRP) failed to qualify for the 2024 presidential nomination <citation>https://www.facebook.com/BotswanaGovernment/posts/%EF%B9%94%EF%B8%8F%EF%B9%94%EF%B8%8F%EF%B9%94%EF%B8%8F%EF%B9%94%EF%B8%8F%EF%B9%94%EF%B8%8F-GENERAL-ELECTIONSPRESIDENTIAL-CANDIDATES-chief-justice-terrence-rannowane-/967695282069217/</citation>.

Prospective candidates for National Assembly and Local Government elections must complete Form O - Nomination Paper, ensuring that it contains endorsements after a Writ of Election or Election Instrument has been issued <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/nomination-candidates-elections</citation>.

Presidential candidates nomination for the 2024 elections was scheduled for September 28, 2024 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>, <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation>.
The President of Botswana alone can announce the exact date of the election <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/announcement-of-date-of-elections-is-presidents-prerogative-iec/</citation>.

The leaders of the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), Botswana Congress Party (BCP), Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), and Botswana Patriot Front (BPF) were declared presidential candidates <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>.
The High Court headquarters are in Gaborone, with other locations in Lobatse, Francistown and Maun <citation>https://www.gov.bw/legal/hierarchy-courts</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) conducts elections according to Botswana's electoral legal framework and internationally recognized principles <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>.

The four confirmed presidential candidates for the 2024 election were Mokgweetsi Masisi, Duma Boko, Dumelang Saleshando, and Mephato Reatile <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82038</citation>, <citation>https://iafrica.com/high-court-confirms-four-candidates-for-botswanas-upcoming-presidential-election/</citation>.

Presidential candidates are required to be accompanied by 1,000 nomination forms verified and stamped by Botswana Police Station commanders <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>.

By law, presidential candidates must provide proof to the Chief Justice that they have the required number of supporters to be eligible to run <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2024/10/01/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates/</citation>.

The Botswana Police Service (BPS) plays a crucial role in ensuring a safe and secure environment for the general elections <citation>https://www.facebook.com/BotswanaPoliceService/posts/996446029188443/</citation>.

### Presidential nominees

The nomination of presidential candidates in Botswana is a process governed by a specific legal framework and involves several key steps. The primary legal documents outlining this process are Sections 30-35 of the Botswana Constitution of 1966 <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation> and the Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>, <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/StatutesActpdf/1969Actpdf/PRESIDENTIAL+ELECTIONS+(SUPPLEMENTARY+PROVISIONS)+ACT,+41+OF+1969.pdf</citation>, <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/consolidated-statutes/principle-legislation/presidential-elections-supplementary-provisions</citation>.

Nomination day is a critical date, statutorily defined as the first Saturday following the expiry of 20 days after each dissolution of the National Assembly <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/StatutesActpdf/1969Actpdf/PRESIDENTIAL+ELECTIONS+(SUPPLEMENTARY+PROVISIONS)+ACT,+41+OF+1969.pdf</citation>. On this day, nominations must be delivered to the returning officer <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation>, who is then responsible for examining the nomination papers <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/Presidential+Elections+Supplementary+Provisions+ch02-01.pdf</citation> to ensure they meet the legal requirements outlined in section 5 of the Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/Presidential+Elections+Supplementary+Provisions+ch02-01.pdf</citation>.

A key requirement for a valid presidential nomination is demonstrating sufficient support. According to the law, a nomination is not valid unless it is supported in the manner prescribed <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation>. Presidential candidates must provide proof to the chief justice that they have the required number of supporters to be eligible to run <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2024/10/01/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates/</citation>. This includes being accompanied by 1,000 nomination forms, verified and officially stamped by Botswana Police Station commanders stationed at various constituencies across the country <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>.

The Chief Justice plays a significant role in the nomination process, primarily by confirming the candidates after reviewing their applications <citation>https://sundiatapost.com/4-nominees-submit-application-for-botswana-presidency-election-body/</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) is responsible for the overall conduct and supervision of elections <citation>https://www.gov.bw/ministries/independent-electoral-commission</citation>, ensuring that the elections are conducted efficiently, properly, freely, and fairly <citation>https://www.gov.bw/ministries/independent-electoral-commission</citation>.
To be nominated, candidates must produce an official receipt of P500.00 for election to the National Assembly or P100.00 in the case of election to a Council, or deposit the said amounts in cash with the Returning Officer <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/parties-and-candidates.html</citation>.

The IEC has registered only 736,424 prospective voters for the 2024 General Election <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-records-a-decline-in-registered-voters/news</citation>.

There were administrative and logistical issues with the voter registration exercise, but it was largely successful <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

IEC Secretary Jeff Siamisang stated that the voter registration process was slated for January 5 to February 3, 2024, in advance of the parliamentary and local government elections <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/voter-registration-for-next-years-general-elections-in-botswana-to-start-friday</citation>.

IEC exceeded a historic 1 million mark in voter registration. Women accounted for 54% of registered voters, men 46%, and youth 32% <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-exceeds-historic-1-million-mark-in-voter-registration/</citation>.

During general registration periods, non-residents can go to the Botswana Embassy, consular mission or other location specified in the newspaper announcement to check the voters' roll <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

The IEC opened an estimated 2,880 polling stations across Botswana, along with an additional 48 polling stations in foreign territories, to facilitate voter registration for Batswana citizens residing abroad <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>, <citation>https://english.news.cn/africa/20240106/a878148cf9754885917ec6ffb2aaffdd/c.html</citation>.

The voter registration exercise encountered issues on its first day, which could potentially undermine the credibility of the registration process and the country's democratic integrity <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

Every resident and non-resident citizen of Botswana who is eighteen years and above qualifies to register as a voter <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9&Itemid=111</citation>.

To vote in National and Local Government elections in Botswana, citizens aged 18 and over must register with the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) and obtain a voter registration card <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>, <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) provides general registration periods where eligible citizens can verify their inclusion on the voterâ€™s rolls and register if they are not included <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

During general registration periods, non-residents can visit the Botswana Embassy, consular mission, or other specified locations to check the voters' roll <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>, <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php?title=Botswana_-_Obtain_a_Voters_card</citation>.

The voter registration challenges include voter apathy, and some stakeholders believed the IEC failed to adequately educate eligible voters <citation>https://www.up.ac.za/news/post_3252222-up-expert-opinion-up-expert-assesses-botswanas-state-of-readiness-for-2024-elections</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) will announce a general registration period when citizens can verify their inclusion on the voterâ€™s rolls, and if not included, they can register to be added <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>, <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.
The voter should have a valid National Identity Card and Voter Registration Card to vote on election day <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) of Botswana initiated the voter registration process on January 5, 2024, with the exercise scheduled to conclude on February 3, 2024, in preparation for the general elections later in the year <citation>https://africanyouthnews.com/botswana-begins-voter-registration-for-upcoming-election-despite-challenges/</citation>, <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/botswana-begins-voter-registration-for-upcoming-election-despite-challenges</citation>.

The anticipated voting population for the 2024 general election, as projected by the IEC, was 1.7 million, and the Commission targeted an 80% registration rate, aiming for approximately 1.3 million registered voters <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>.

To register, one must present themself to a Registration Officer with a valid National Identity Card (Omang) to complete a registration form <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>, <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

Since January 5, 2024, a total 319,632 eligible voters have been captured, and 130,541 people were registered in week two <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/iec-numbers-decline-maroba-expresses-no-worry/news</citation>.

The IEC postponed the national voter registration exercise indefinitely because of an ongoing legal battle with the opposition Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) party <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/botswana-electoral-turmoil-deepens</citation>.

The IEC postponed voter registration to implement measures aimed at delivering a higher quality registration process <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/iec-postpones-voter-registration</citation>.

The voter registration card is issued and voters are advised to keep it safe for presentation at election time <citation>https://www.facebook.com/iecbotswana/posts/voter-registration-requirements-and-processevery-citizen-of-botswana-who-is-eigh/1692976917523459/</citation>.

The total number of registered voters for the 2024 general elections represents an increase of 112,800 people compared to the 2019 general elections, where 925,478 people registered to vote <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/over-one-million-voters-for-2024-elections/</citation>.

Voter registration is conducted to create a new voters roll before every general election at established polling stations both locally and internationally <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=9&Itemid=111</citation>.

### Observation controversy

The 2024 Botswana general elections saw significant participation from various observer groups, both international and local, reflecting a commitment to ensuring the integrity and transparency of the electoral process. The Electoral Commissions Forum for SADC Countries (ECF-SADC) <citation>https://www.ecfsadc.org/preliminary-statement-of-the-ecf-sadc-election-observation-mission-to-the-general-elections-of-the-republic-of-botswana/</citation> and the SADC Electoral Observation Mission (SEOM) <citation>https://www.sadc.int/latest-news/sadc-electoral-observation-mission-seom-2024-general-elections-republic-botswana</citation> were deployed to observe the pre-election phase, polling day, and post-election processes. Locally, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) formed "Madibelatlhopho," a vigilante group, to monitor voter registration, alleging potential rigging <citation>https://africaelects.com/2024/10/28/botswana-inside-the-countrys-most-competitive-election-to-date/</citation>. The Zimbabwe Election Support Network (ZESN) also observed the elections <citation>https://www.zesn.org.zw/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/ZESN-ESN-SA-Botswana-Election-Report.pdf</citation>.

However, the voter registration process was marked by considerable controversy. A significant point of contention was the UDC's demand to deploy its observers across the country, a move initially resisted by the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/botswana-electoral-turmoil-deepens</citation>. This disagreement led to a legal battle, with the UDC taking the IEC to court to secure the right to monitor the registration process <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>. The IEC's opposition stemmed from the absence of specific legal provisions mandating the presence of party agents during voter registration <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281573770483750</citation>.

The legal dispute resulted in multiple postponements of the voter registration exercise <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation><citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/botswana-electoral-turmoil-deepens</citation>. The High Court ruled in favor of the UDC, granting them the right to observe and monitor the process, including recording names and ID numbers of registrants <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/iec-postpones-voter-registration-process</citation>. Subsequently, the IEC appealed the High Court ruling <citation>https://www.gabzfm.com/post/iec-appeals-court-order-allowing-udc-to-monitor-voter-registration</citation>. Despite these challenges, voter registration eventually commenced on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://english.news.cn/20231231/574ef47489eb4622a2bca5971272ea17/c.html</citation>. Preliminary statements from observer missions indicated that the 2024 general elections were conducted in a free and peaceful atmosphere <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82930</citation>.

final_report:
## Campaign

The lead-up to the 2024 Botswana general election was marked by energetic public discourse and diverse party platforms <citation>https://www.botswanayouth.com/botswana-2024-general-elections/</citation>. Key issues reflected the evolving priorities of Batswana, including concerns about the minimum wage <citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation>, rising unemployment, and economic uncertainty <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation>.

The ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), which had been in power for 58 years since independence <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>, launched its manifesto with a pledge to focus on creating jobs, strengthening financial systems, and upholding democracy <citation>https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/africa/2024-09-02-botswanas-president-masisi-launches-bdp-manifesto-ahead-of-2024-elections</citation>. President Masisi described the manifesto as a realistic program grounded in the realities faced by Batswana <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81509</citation>.

The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), which ultimately won the election, centered its campaign on "inclusive growth and quality lives" <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. A key promise was the creation of 450,000 to 500,000 jobs in five years to combat the staggering unemployment rate <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241122/281608130987055</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. The UDC also pledged to increase the average salary to P10,000 or more, achieve an annual economic growth rate of at least 10%, and launch a National Community Service program with a monthly allowance of P2,500 <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/udc-unveils-inclusive-growth-quality-lives-election-manifesto/</citation>. A significant proposal was to more than double the minimum wage to 4,000 pula ($300) per month <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-elections-ruling-party-seeks-to-extend-58-years-in-power</citation>, although concerns were raised about the feasibility and potential impact on businesses <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/business-botswana-not-ready-for-p4k-minimum-wage/</citation>. Businesses, particularly those in manufacturing and agriculture, warned of severe challenges and suggested a phased implementation of the minimum wage increase <citation>https://thevoicebw.com/business-botswana-not-ready-for-p4k-minimum-wage/</citation>.

Other parties, such as the Botswana Congress Party (BCP), also presented their manifestos, with the BCP focusing on improving lives through a high-wage economy and democratic governance <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82075</citation>.
## Election date and timeline

The Botswana general election was held on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation><citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation><citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation><citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation><citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240904/botswanas-general-election-set-for-october-30-1068142775.html</citation>. This marked the 13th post-independence general election in the country <citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation>.

The lead-up to the election involved several key events. Voter registration concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://newsinvasion24.com/botswana-wraps-up-voter-registration-for-2024-elections/</citation>. Presidential nominees were validated by the High Court <citation>https://www.africauptodate.com/botswana-general-elections-2024-begin</citation>, and political parties nominated their parliamentary and council candidates. The 12th Parliament of Botswana was dissolved on September 5th, 2024 <citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://parliament.gov.bw/documents/PARLY-SPREAD-2024F_01_25_02_18_09_2024.pdf</citation>, in accordance with Section 90, Sub-Section 3 of the Constitution <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation>. The President is mandated by the Constitution to call for general elections within 60 days of Parliament's dissolution <citation>https://www.facebook.com/BotswanaGovernment/posts/sequence-of-events-towards-the-12th-parliament-dissolution-of-parliamentin-terms/2450889864993657/</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation>.

General elections in Botswana are held every five years after the expiry of one life of Parliament <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>. Botswana's elections are governed by the 1966 Constitution, the 1969 Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act, the 1968 Electoral Act and the 2012 Local Government Act <citation>https://www.esn-sa.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Botswana-Elections-Key-Insights-.pdf</citation>.
## Preface

The 2024 Botswana general election, held on October 30, 2024 <citation>https://povonews.com/botswanas-2024-general-elections-to-be-held-on-october-30/</citation><citation>https://www.voanews.com/a/botswana-to-hold-elections-october-30-as-president-masisi-seeks-2nd-term-/7770173.html</citation><citation>https://africacenter.org/spotlight/2024-elections/botswana/</citation><citation>https://www.okayafrica.com/botswana-general-elections/</citation><citation>https://www.mmegi.bw/news/botswana-election-to-be-held-october-30th/news</citation><citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/30-october-is-election-day/</citation><citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/botswana-general-election-set-for-october-30-20240903</citation><citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81548</citation><citation>https://en.sputniknews.africa/20240904/botswanas-general-election-set-for-october-30-1068142775.html</citation>, marked a watershed moment in the nation's political landscape. For the first time in 58 years since independence, the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) was ousted from power <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/11/1/botswanas-ruling-party-loses-power-after-six-decades-early-results-show</citation>, as the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a majority with 59.0% of the vote, securing 36 out of 61 National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>. This election saw Duma Boko of the UDC emerge victorious, while the incumbent President Mokgweetsi Masisi conceded defeat <citation>https://www.theglobeandmail.com/world/article-opposition-party-wins-overwhelming-majority-in-botswana-election/</citation>.

Several critical issues dominated the electoral discourse, including rising unemployment <citation>https://blog.bti-project.org/2024/08/29/a-bumpy-road-ahead-botswana-faces-economic-and-political-struggles-ahead-of-its-2024-general-elections/</citation> and a proposed minimum wage increase to P4,000 <citation>https://www.regalcapital.org/p/should-botswana-increase-minimum-wage-to-p4000</citation>, a significant jump from the existing P1,321 <citation>https://www.regalcapital.org/p/should-botswana-increase-minimum-wage-to-p4000</citation>. The UDC campaigned on a platform of "inclusive growth and quality lives," promising the creation of 450,000 to 500,000 jobs <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/botswana-guardian/20241122/281608130987055</citation> and reforms in education, housing, and healthcare <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/features/umbrella-for-democratic-change-udc-manifesto-highlights/</citation>.

The peaceful transfer of power following the election has been hailed as a triumph of democracy in Southern Africa <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, underscoring Botswana's commitment to regular democratic elections since gaining independence in 1966 <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. Duma Boko's inauguration marked a new political era <citation>https://myafrikamag.com/president-duma-bokos-inauguration-a-vision-of-unity-progress-and-renewal-for-botswana/</citation>, with a strong emphasis on unity and progress <citation>https://www.news24.com/news24/politics/together-we-usher-a-new-political-dawn-says-botswana-president-duma-boko-in-inauguration-speech-20241108</citation>.
## Results

The 2024 Botswana general election marked a historic shift in the nation's political landscape, ending the Botswana Democratic Party's (BDP) nearly six-decade rule since gaining independence in 1966 <citation>https://apnews.com/article/botswana-election-masisi-concedes-80951b62fdb7169f073c2b13acaff1b6</citation>. Voters rejected the long-serving governing party in what has been described as a political earthquake <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.

In terms of seat distribution, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured a majority of the vote with 59.0%, gaining 36 out of the 61 elected National Assembly seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) won 15 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) secured five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The BDP's share of seats drastically declined from 38 in 2019 (out of 57) to a mere 4 (out of 61 directly elected seats) in the 69-member Parliament <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

Concerning the vote share, the UDC secured 36.9% of the total votes, surpassing the BDP, which received 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) maintained a substantial presence with 20.7% of the votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP)'s share of support dropped to 31% in the October 2024 elections, resulting in only four out of 61 constituencies <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) victory in the 2024 election is considered the biggest upset in the country's election history <citation>https://www.africanews.com/2024/11/01/botswana-udc-supporters-celebrate-election-win/</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.
## Voter registration

In Botswana, every citizen aged 18 years and above is eligible to register to vote in National and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php?title=Botswana_-_Obtain_a_Voters_card</citation>, <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/elections.html</citation>. The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) conducts voter registration, a process which involves eligible citizens verifying their inclusion on the voter's roll or registering to be added <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>.

The voter registration for the 2024 general elections began on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://africanyouthnews.com/botswana-begins-voter-registration-for-upcoming-election-despite-challenges/</citation>, <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/voter-registration-for-next-years-general-elections-in-botswana-to-start-friday</citation>. Supplementary voter registration periods were also announced, with one running from February 26 to March 15, 2024 <citation>https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/supplementary-voting-registration-2024-elections-easylaw-botswana-9hdgf</citation>. To register, citizens are required to present themselves to a Registration Officer with a valid National Identity Card (Omang) <citation>https://www.gov.bw/voting/voter-registration</citation>, <citation>https://www.wikiprocedure.com/index.php/Botswana_-_Register_as_Voter</citation>. The IEC also set up approximately 2,880 polling stations across Botswana and 48 in foreign territories to accommodate Batswana citizens living abroad <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>.

The IEC, however, faced several challenges during the registration process, including some registration clerks arriving late or not showing up <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/voter-registration-challenges-undermine-elections-integrity</citation>. There was also a surge in illegal voter registrations <citation>https://apadiaspora.net/botswana-poll-body-warns-of-surge-in-voter-registration-irregularities/</citation>. To combat this, the IEC dispelled fears of electoral fraud related to recent ID issues, stating that multiple registrations and underage registrants are common mistakes that will be addressed through voter roll inspections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/iec-dispels-electoral-fraud-in-recent-id-issues/</citation>. The IEC also postponed the voter registration process to ensure quality registration <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/74700</citation>.
### Background of opposition parties before the election

The 2024 Botswana general election saw a number of opposition parties vying for power, most notably the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC), the Botswana Congress Party (BCP), the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF), and the Alliance for Progressives (AP) <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/botswanas-political-landscape-gearing-up-for-the-2024-general-election</citation>. The UDC is a coalition of left-leaning parties aiming to unseat the BDP <citation>https://www.theafricareport.com/366164/botswanas-presidential-election-meet-the-candidates/</citation>. Led by Duma Boko, the UDC was formed in 2012 by three political parties: the Botswana National Front, the Botswana Movement for Democracy, and the Botswana People's Party <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2024/11/12/botswanas-new-president-who-is-duma-boko-and-what-does-he-stand-for/</citation>. Boko served as the Leader of the Opposition in the National Assembly from 2014 to 2019 <citation>https://kids.kiddle.co/Duma_Boko</citation>. In the 2024 election, the UDC secured 36.9% of the total votes <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>.

The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) has promised to "save Botswana" and committed to offering an average monthly living wage of 4,000 pula <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. Dumelang Saleshando is the leader of the BCP <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. The BCP secured 15 seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) was formed by ex-President Ian Khama's followers <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation> just before the 2019 election <citation>https://nation.africa/africa/news/-botswana-s-election-shock-why-voters-kicked-the-ruling-party-out-after-58-years-4821024</citation>. Mephato Reatile leads the BPF <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>. The BPF won five seats in the 2024 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The Alliance for Progressives (AP) is a dynamic and forward-thinking political movement dedicated to transforming Botswana into a nation of equal opportunities, inclusive growth, and sustainable prosperity <citation>https://www.ap.org.bw/about/</citation>.

Former President Ian Khama split from the BDP and supported the BPF <citation>https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c238n5zr51yo</citation>.
### Composition of parliament

The Botswana National Assembly is a unicameral legislature. The most recent 2024 election and preceding years have seen some shifts in its composition. The new legislature consists of 69 members <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, an increase from the previous 65. This number includes 61 directly elected members <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation> who are chosen through a First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) system <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, six specially elected members who are indirectly elected by the National Assembly <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>, and two *ex officio* members: the President and the Speaker <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The Speaker may be appointed from outside the National Assembly <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

The 2019 election saw the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) win a majority with 38 of the 57 seats being voted on <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/4357/</citation>. Voter turnout was 84% <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/4357/</citation>. However, the 2024 election resulted in a significant shift in power, ending the BDP's 58-year rule <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) secured 36 seats <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation>, while the BDP's representation plummeted to just 4 seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) secured 15 seats and the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won five seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>. Overall voter turnout was 79% in the 2024 elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82973</citation>.

Prior to 2023, the National Assembly saw instances of floor crossing. For example, two BDP MPs and two UDC MPs defected to the UDC and BDP, respectively <citation>https://www.wikiwand.com/en/articles/2024_Botswana_general_election</citation>. To address this, a ban on floor crossing was implemented in 2023, mandating that MPs resign if they switch parties mid-term <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>. This amendment aims to stabilize governance and respect voter mandates <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/floor-crossing-ban-reshapes-political-accountability</citation>.

Notably, Yandani Boko resigned from his position as MP for Mahalapye East during this period <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/youngest-botswana-mp-resigns-rumors</citation>.

In the 2024 parliamentary elections, only 28 women stood for parliament out of 258 contestants, representing 10.85% of the total candidates. Only three women won their seats, representing 4.92% of the 61 seats <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/women-in-botswana-make-up-54-of-voters-but-less-than-10-of-parliament-political-parties-can-change-that</citation>.
### Previous election

The 2019 Botswana General Election, held on October 23, 2019, marked the 12th consecutive win for the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) since the country's independence in 1966 <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2019/10/27/he-mokgweetsi-masisi-bdp-wins-botswana-2019-general-election/</citation>. This victory secured President Mokgweetsi Masisi's mandate to implement the BDP's promises <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2019/10/27/he-mokgweetsi-masisi-bdp-wins-botswana-2019-general-election/</citation>.

Key political parties in the 2019 election included the Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), and the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) <citation>http://archive.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2041_E.htm</citation>.

The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP) secured a majority, winning 38 out of the 57 contested seats <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/52572</citation>. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) won 15 seats <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20191023/</citation>, the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) won 3, and the Alliance for Progressives (AP) won 1 <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/52572</citation>.

Voter turnout was significant, with 84% of registered voters participating <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>, representing 777,943 votes cast <citation>https://www.thefreelibrary.com/Fluctuating+voting+trends+in+Botswana.-a0779611920</citation>. 925,478 people registered to vote in 2019 <citation>https://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/29/</citation>.

The election saw some controversies, including concerns about the fairness of the electoral system <citation>https://www.academia.edu/40308652/The_2019_Elections_in_Botswana_Context_History_and_Future_Chris_Brown</citation> and allegations of double voting <citation>https://www.biznews.com/global-citizen/2019/12/05/botswana-election-rigged-forensics-justice</citation>. The Electoral Amendment Act of 2016, introducing electronic voting, also caused controversy <citation>https://freedomhouse.org/country/botswana/freedom-world/2019</citation>.

Former President Ian Khama's strained relationship with his successor, Mokgweetsi Masisi, significantly impacted the 2019 elections, with Khama supporting the opposition in an attempt to unseat Masisi and the BDP <citation>https://converis.ub.bw/converis/portal/detail/Publication/9692048?lang=en_GB</citation>.

International observer missions, such as the ECF-SADC, were present to observe the election <citation>https://www.eisa.org/pdf/bot2019ecf.pdf</citation> and hailed the polls as credible and a fair reflection of the will of the people <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/52573</citation>.

Following the election, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) challenged the results in court, focusing on 16 parliamentary constituencies won by the BDP <citation>https://www.reuters.com/article/world/botswana-opposition-challenges-election-result-in-court-idUSKBN1Y00QO/</citation>.
### Seat redistribution

Botswana employs a First-Past-The-Post (FPTP) majority system for both National Assembly and Local Government elections <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. This system dictates that the candidate with the most votes in a constituency wins the seat <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. Following the October 30, 2024, general election <citation>https://www.princetonpoliticalreview.org/international-news/botswanas-political-shake-up-what-the-ruling-partys-historic-loss-means-for-democracy-in-sadc</citation>, the seat distribution in the National Assembly saw a dramatic shift. The Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) emerged as the leading party, securing 36 of the 61 directly elected seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>, marking a significant increase from the 15 seats they held after the 2019 election <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20191023/</citation>. The Botswana Congress Party (BCP) won 15 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>, while the Botswana Patriotic Front (BPF) secured 5 seats <citation>https://www.idea.int/democracytracker/report/botswana/october-2024</citation>. The Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), which had dominated Botswana's politics since 1969 <citation>https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/10/30/botswana-election-who-is-in-the-running-and-whats-at-stake</citation>, experienced a historic defeat, plummeting to just 4 seats <citation>https://www.journalofdemocracy.org/elections/election-results-october-through-december-2024/</citation> from 38 in 2019 <citation>https://data.ipu.org/parliament/BW/BW-LC01/election/BW-LC01-E20241030/</citation>.

This outcome highlights the potential disparities that can arise under the FPTP electoral system, where a party can win the majority of seats without necessarily securing the majority of total votes cast <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. For example, in the 2024 election, the UDC won with 36.9% of the total votes, while the BDP secured 30.2% <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>. As an alternative, a Proportional Representation (PR) system would allocate seats more closely mirroring the actual voter preferences <citation>https://www.tdghrconsults.com/post/botswana-s-2024-election-milestone-and-the-quest-for-true-representation</citation>, potentially leading to a more representative legislature.
### MPs not standing for re-election

The 2024 Botswana general election saw a number of Members of Parliament not standing for re-election for various reasons. Some MPs' political careers came to an end due to losses in primary elections, while others opted for retirement <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>. For instance, in the Gaborone North constituency, the incumbent MP, Mpho Balopi, had announced that he would not seek re-election in the 2024 general elections <citation>https://www.thegazette.news/news/animosity-rises-as-bdp-primaries-near/</citation>. Similarly, Dr. Thapelo Matsheka, the Member of Parliament for Lobatse, decided not to seek re-election in the coming general elections <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/80969</citation>. He expressed his gratitude to the people of Lobatse for the opportunity to represent them <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/80969</citation>. Additionally, Pono Moatlhodi, the Tonota Member of Parliament, fueled speculation surrounding his political future and did not contest the 2024 election <citation>https://www.pressreader.com/botswana/mmegi/20230804/281595245044445</citation>. Eric Molale, Good Hope/Mabule constituency MP, also announced that he would not be seeking re-election in this year's general elections <citation>https://www.africa-press.net/botswana/all-news/molale-bids-constituents-farewell</citation>. The exodus, particularly by MPs from the ruling Botswana Democratic Party (BDP), was spurred by losses in the Bulela Ditswe primary elections, paving the way for new faces <citation>https://thepatriot.co.bw/adios-to-retiring-mps/</citation>.
### Presidential nominees

The nomination of presidential candidates in Botswana is a process governed by a specific legal framework and involves several key steps. The primary legal documents outlining this process are Sections 30-35 of the Botswana Constitution of 1966 <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation> and the Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>, <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/StatutesActpdf/1969Actpdf/PRESIDENTIAL+ELECTIONS+(SUPPLEMENTARY+PROVISIONS)+ACT,+41+OF+1969.pdf</citation>, <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/consolidated-statutes/principle-legislation/presidential-elections-supplementary-provisions</citation>.

Nomination day is a critical date, statutorily defined as the first Saturday following the expiry of 20 days after each dissolution of the National Assembly <citation>https://botswanalaws.com/StatutesActpdf/1969Actpdf/PRESIDENTIAL+ELECTIONS+(SUPPLEMENTARY+PROVISIONS)+ACT,+41+OF+1969.pdf</citation>. On this day, nominations must be delivered to the returning officer <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation>, who is then responsible for examining the nomination papers <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/Presidential+Elections+Supplementary+Provisions+ch02-01.pdf</citation> to ensure they meet the legal requirements outlined in section 5 of the Presidential Elections (Supplementary Provisions) Act <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/images/Presidential+Elections+Supplementary+Provisions+ch02-01.pdf</citation>.

A key requirement for a valid presidential nomination is demonstrating sufficient support. According to the law, a nomination is not valid unless it is supported in the manner prescribed <citation>https://www.lawglobalhub.com/section-30-35-botswana-constitution-1966/</citation>. Presidential candidates must provide proof to the chief justice that they have the required number of supporters to be eligible to run <citation>https://yourbotswana.com/2024/10/01/botswana-leader-3-from-opposition-confirmed-as-presidential-candidates/</citation>. This includes being accompanied by 1,000 nomination forms, verified and officially stamped by Botswana Police Station commanders stationed at various constituencies across the country <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/81985</citation>.

The Chief Justice plays a significant role in the nomination process, primarily by confirming the candidates after reviewing their applications <citation>https://sundiatapost.com/4-nominees-submit-application-for-botswana-presidency-election-body/</citation>.

The Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) is responsible for the overall conduct and supervision of elections <citation>https://www.gov.bw/ministries/independent-electoral-commission</citation>, ensuring that the elections are conducted efficiently, properly, freely, and fairly <citation>https://www.gov.bw/ministries/independent-electoral-commission</citation>.
To be nominated, candidates must produce an official receipt of P500.00 for election to the National Assembly or P100.00 in the case of election to a Council, or deposit the said amounts in cash with the Returning Officer <citation>https://www.iec.gov.bw/index.php/parties-and-candidates.html</citation>.
### Observation controversy

The 2024 Botswana general elections saw significant participation from various observer groups, both international and local, reflecting a commitment to ensuring the integrity and transparency of the electoral process. The Electoral Commissions Forum for SADC Countries (ECF-SADC) <citation>https://www.ecfsadc.org/preliminary-statement-of-the-ecf-sadc-election-observation-mission-to-the-general-elections-of-the-republic-of-botswana/</citation> and the SADC Electoral Observation Mission (SEOM) <citation>https://www.sadc.int/latest-news/sadc-electoral-observation-mission-seom-2024-general-elections-republic-botswana</citation> were deployed to observe the pre-election phase, polling day, and post-election processes. Locally, the Umbrella for Democratic Change (UDC) formed "Madibelatlhopho," a vigilante group, to monitor voter registration, alleging potential rigging <citation>https://africaelects.com/2024/10/28/botswana-inside-the-countrys-most-competitive-election-to-date/</citation>. The Zimbabwe Election Support Network (ZESN) also observed the elections <citation>https://www.zesn.org.zw/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/ZESN-ESN-SA-Botswana-Election-Report.pdf</citation>.

However, the voter registration process was marked by considerable controversy. A significant point of contention was the UDC's demand to deploy its observers across the country, a move initially resisted by the Independent Electoral Commission (IEC) <citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/botswana-electoral-turmoil-deepens</citation>. This disagreement led to a legal battle, with the UDC taking the IEC to court to secure the right to monitor the registration process <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation>. The IEC's opposition stemmed from the absence of specific legal provisions mandating the presence of party agents during voter registration <citation>https://enews.mmegi.bw/article/281573770483750</citation>.

The legal dispute resulted in multiple postponements of the voter registration exercise <citation>https://trendsnafrica.com/voter-registration-for-2024-general-elections-starts-in-botswana/</citation><citation>https://africabrief.substack.com/p/botswana-electoral-turmoil-deepens</citation>. The High Court ruled in favor of the UDC, granting them the right to observe and monitor the process, including recording names and ID numbers of registrants <citation>https://guardiansun.co.bw/news/politics/iec-postpones-voter-registration-process</citation>. Subsequently, the IEC appealed the High Court ruling <citation>https://www.gabzfm.com/post/iec-appeals-court-order-allowing-udc-to-monitor-voter-registration</citation>. Despite these challenges, voter registration eventually commenced on January 5 and concluded on February 3, 2024 <citation>https://english.news.cn/20231231/574ef47489eb4622a2bca5971272ea17/c.html</citation>. Preliminary statements from observer missions indicated that the 2024 general elections were conducted in a free and peaceful atmosphere <citation>https://dailynews.gov.bw/news-detail/82930</citation>.
